title: Tuesday, 25th October, 2016

11:14 am
BE

Here's Morgan Stanley's summary, for what it's worth.

PM

(Actually, I spoke to soon -- looks like we do have a bond bail-in)

BE

Monte Paschi business plan targets greater than 11% ROTE and €1.1bn net
profit in 2019E. We believe the targets are ambitious, as with
4.6% cost cutting they rely heavily on a recovery in both NII
and Fees. We also have no further details on LME and/or
anchor investors, hence we believe execution risks remain.
Monte Paschi business plan is targeting €1.1bn Net Income in 2019E. This implies
over 11% ROTE with a cost income ratio of c. 55%, a 55bp cost of risk and a tax
rate of 22%. Non performing loans would be reduced from 18.6% proforma in Q3
to 16.2% in 2019, and CET1 would increase to 13.5% from above 11% at the end of
2016.
Cost base is expected to be at €2.5bn in 2019E, down 4.6% vs. 2016 pro-forma.
The company is targeting a 9% reduction in staff costs to €1.5bn in 2019,
including a 2600 reduction in headcount. Admin expenses are expected to be
down 4% to €710mn including the reduction of 500 branches, 25% of total.
On top of the capital increase of up to €5bn for which BMPS has a preunderwriting agreement with a pool of banks, the company announced it is in the
process of selling its merchant bank ICBPI for €520m.
The fact that the improvement in profitability is driven by a recovery in revenues
vs. lower costs (the carve out of NPLs was already known) could raise some
concerns among investors, in our view. Additionally we have no updates on any
anchor investors or on the tender offer to convert junior debt holders, which
leads us to believe execution risks to raising €5bn of capital in the private market
remain.

11:15 am
BE

And Goldman's.

BE

Analysis
The key highlight of the business plan is a net profit target of €1.0-1.1 bn
for 2018-2019E (or 10%-11% ROTE). Compared to our 2016 forecast, this is
based on (1) a NII CAGR of 3% and a fee income CAGR of 5%, (2) cost
reduction of 2% per annum, leading to pre-provision income of
€1.8-2.1 bn, for 2018-2019E, (3) cost of risk of 65-70 bp in 2018 and 55 bp in
2019E and (4) a low tax rate of 1%-12% thanks to DTAs. The biggest
differences to our 2019E forecasts are partly linked to top line (€0.1 bn
higher), but lower costs, provisions and taxes (€0.2 bn lower each) are the
biggest difference. We thus see the composition of the P&L as more
credible than if it had been based on high pre-provision income growth.
The capital plan continues to include a capital raise of up €5 bn to finance
the loss on the sale of €28 bn of NPLs at 33c/€, but it has three main
updates: (1) it features a potential voluntary debt for equity swap to fill part
of the €5 bn, followed by (2) a capital increase with no pre-emption rights
which (3) is planned to be carried out before year-end, regulatory
authorization allowing.
Implications
The business plan targets are a positive in our opinion, as they are based
on low costs, LLPs and taxes, rather than optimistic revenue assumptions.
This is also incrementally positive for the completion of BMPS’ capital
raise, which has a beneficial read-across for other Italian banks. For the
share price, however, the exclusion of pre-emption rights for the capital
hike adds uncertainty. Our Neutral rating and price target remain
unchanged. We value MPS using a capital-adjusted ROTE/COE
methodology, and our 12m price target is €0.26. Key up/downside risks
include unforeseen change in sovereign, macro, asset quality and
regulatory situation.

BE

And with that I'll leave the right to discuss whether we're in Milan, Madrid or Tuscany.

11:25 am
BE

Anyway, back to Whitbread.

BE

UBS with the capsule summary, for those with very short elevator rides before meeting clients.

BE

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: Revenues in line, PBT 1 -2% beat, reduced room openings. H1 Revs of £1.56bn
(UBSe/Cons £1.56bn), PBT £307m (UBSe £295m, Cons £302m). Hotels/Restaurants
EBIT £271.5m (UBSe £258m, Cons£262m), Costa EBIT £65m (UBSe £70m, Cons
£71m).
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Premier Inn RevPAR was -0.2% in H1 (UBSe 0.7%), with implied Q2 at 0.1%. This
drove PI LFL sales of 2.4% (2.1% in Q1). Costa LFLs were 2.3% implying 2% in Q2
(2.6% Q1). EBIT margins are up 60bps in WHR (UBSe down -20bps) and 180bps down
in Costa (UBSe -80bps), due to the phasing of investments.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: Room openings for Fy16/17 reduced to 3700 (previously c5000). However, the
company expects to deliver in line with FY expectations.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: While the PBT number is a beat, we expect the deceleration of LFLs coupled with the
lower room opening guidance to drive a negative share price reaction today.

11:27 am
BE

And Barclays with a bit more.

BE

Actually, not Barclays. The Barclays note is really dull. Have Canaccord instead.

BE

The interims were fractionally better than we expected and full year results should
remain 'in line' with expectations. However, the mix of EBIT was slightly different with a
stronger Premier Inn performance offsetting a weaker Costa result. Whitbread's share
price has lacked direction this year, following its 30% fall from last year's high-point,
instead taking its cue from macro-events rather than any company-inspired progress
and we expect the stock to remain range-bound. We remain buyers given the excellent
underlying FCF and strong balance sheet, which gives it significant resilience and
optionality.

11:29 am
BE

Premier Inn EBIT was +8.9% to £271.5m driven by sales growth of 8.9% and helped by
the cost efficiency benefits starting to feed through. It remains the powerhouse of the
company but there was a divergence of performance between the regions and provinces.
Regional Premier Inn sales grew 9.7%, driven by six new hotels opened, occupancy of
81.9% and L4L sales growth of 3.8%. Regional L4L RevPar was +1.1% with extensions
diluting underlying RevPar by c1.7%. London H1 total RevPar was -6.8% and L4L RevPAr
was -5.5% in line with the market due to subdued corporate demand. Restaurants L4L
sales were just ahead in a soft market.
Costa grew total sales +10.7% with UK equity L4L sales +2.3% but EBIT fell by 4% to
£64.6m due to P&L investment in refurbishments, IT spend and the early introduction
of NLW. There is clearly some 'catch-up' opex going into the business as well as some
interesting new initiatives coming out of the business.
A couple of new hotels have slipped into the next financial year reducing headline
opening to c3,700 new rooms but having no material impact. Costa remains on track to
open 230-250 new stores and install greater than 1,250 new Costa Express machines this year. Full year capex should be in the range of £650m to £700m.
Whitbread's balance sheet strength and FCF generation gives Brittain the firepower to
drive the increased momentum she wishes to push into the organisation. Whitbread
should generate c£360m FCF in FY16E rising to +£530m by 2020E. We forecast net
debt/EBITDA of 1.2x for FY17.

BE

Valuation
Our 5000p target price remains based on DCF and Quest® valuations. It is equivalent to
c20x PE for FY17E falling to 18x the following year, which is marginally above the average
for the last five and ten years. At yesterday's close it was trading on a P/E of 15.5x for
FY17E falling to 14.0x for FY18E. It is on an EV/EBITDA of 10.7x falling to 9.9x for the
same periods.
Share price performance catalyst
We expect CEO Alison Brittain to use the Capital Markets Day on Tuesday 29 November
to reveal a tightened grip on Whitbread's agenda and direction. But, ultimately, a
recovering share price will be driven by returns and results. Our one caveat is that travelrelated geo-political events can be unhelpful for short-term sentiment.

BE

(@ROTR: correct me if my experience is wrong here, but it appears that a number of these newfangled coffee shops don't just sell coffee.)

11:32 am
PM

Globo plc is a small technology company founded by a champion windsurfer in Greece 18 years ago and listed on Aim, London’s junior market, by reverse takeover in 2007. Since then it has raised more than €100m from sales of its stock and debt.

It has some legacy businesses, and has made acquisitions, but its biggest business is now Go!Enterprise, software designed to create a secure bit of space for your employer’s data on your personal phone.

However, according to a critical report published by Quintessential Capital Management, a small New York Hedge Fund run by Gabriele Grego, there appear to be problems with reported sales and profits. QCM tried to register an interest to buy the product with 40 different partners, resellers and distributors listed by Globo, without success.

Globo “completely refutes all allegations made in this report”, and has requested a suspension to its stock so it can provide a more detailed response. In the meantime, the question for investors and auditor Grant Thornton is who really buys Globo’s product?

PM

who really buys Globo’s product?

PM

Answer was "no one" -- call the cops

BE

Barclays says:

11:40 am
BE

NATIONAL EXPRESS (OW, PT 385p) – a strong 3Q trading update, with operating profit up 9% in constant currency (vs 3% in 1H and taking 9M growth to 5% in cc and 12% on a reported basis). The group is saying it at least expects to deliver profits, cash flow and gearing in line with targets. Within the mix, North America saw another strong bid season, with average price increases of c4%. In Spain, passenger growth in the 9M was +7% and recent acquisitions are said to be performing well. In bus, National Express continues to perform ahead of the peer group, with commercial revenue growth of +1.5% although concessionary revenue is still under pressure, whilst in coach core revenue growth of +0.6% is described as resilient despite the tough backdrop of UK travel, and revenue management will be fully implemented by year end. A further two acquisitions were made in North America in the period, whilst those acquired last year are delivering a ROIC of +22%. The Moroccan business is bidding for the Casablanca Tramway and National Express also allude to the fact they will be bidding in one new market shortly. Finally NEX has walked away from the Nuremberg S-Bahn contact following lengthy and ongoing challenges by the incumbent but they remain committed to the German Rail market.

BE

And RBC says:

BE

Our view - Cash generation with 3.4% DPS yield, ~7% EPS CAG, 2.5x ND/EBITDA (after currency translation led Net debt uplifts) with a ~8% (2016E), ~9% 2017E
FCF yield on a diversified business mix - for 12.4x 2017E PER. Crucially for NEX we see the future holding:
1. UK challenges in Bus and Coach (29% 2017E EBITA combined):: We see Coach likely to see adverse effects of rail companies discounting to deliver revenues as the UK
economy moves toward stagnation. We think a more innovative revenue management approach may offset some of this, but we recently (14/10/2016) cut Coach profit
forecasts. In UK Bus, we see a risk to profits from volume weakness due to the potential for rising unemployment and weaker consumer spending power (as the UK
potentially moves towards 1970s style stagflation). Again we cut projections recently.
2. Spanish urban bus long-life 'annuity' and long-distance GDP lift benefits: We think the long-duration annuity of Spanish bus urban contracts is generally underappreciated by investors, but offers predictable value. The longer-distance coach concessions have seen concession re-letting delayed (further) and progress on re-bids will
still depend on a the formation of a stable national government to oversee the process. This means further end of concession profit windfalls for NEX, but also means the
cost/payback of investments like deeper revenues management are uncertain.
3. UK and German rail - proof of delivery: c2c's franchise continues to perform well - despite the national investor gloom (we find) about rail and its GDP and central London
employment exposure for S East UK based franchises. We think the outlook for c2C continue to revolve around the ability to offer more competitive journey times - to take
share from other competitors.
4. School Bus - Geography and product mix is key: NEX has School Bus operation that is mostly centred of higher GDP growth states and provinces (mostly west of
Mississippi and Canada) underpinned by population growth demands, but also by Federally supported special needs products.
5. Financial costs - likely heading down, lifting consensus EPS and cash flow: We recently lifted EPS projections (2017E lifted by ~5%) with lower interest costs a large
element in the uplift as the January 2017 £350m 6.25% bond matures.

PM

(GKN LN) Sales in the 9 months to 30 Sept of £6,895m were 21% higher, representing 2% org growth, aided by £474m FX impact and £587m from acquisitions. As expected, the margin was slightly lower due to a £35m restructuring programme, launch costs in GKN Driveline and the absence of the prior year’s one-off benefits in Aerospace.

Org profit was down as a result, primarily due to these one-off items. Ramp-up of A350, A320 and 737 platforms offset lower A330, A380 and 777 sales. Military sales were lower than the prior period, given decline of mature programmes.

Driveline sales were £3,075m, representing 6% organic growth, against global industry growth of 4%. Powder Metallurgy organic sales flat. Pass through of lower raw materials price had a negative impact. Land Systems sales in the period were £534m (vs. £535m), with org sales declining 8%.

On 21 Oct, the Group announces the disposal of the Stromag business for an EV of £177m and immaterially dilutive. As of Jan 2017 Land Systems will cease to operate as a division, with Shafts and Services reporting into Driveline and Wheels and Structures moving to Other Businesses. FY guidance is maintained.

The outlook for end markets is one of tougher conditions in 2017, in line with the global economic outlook. Automotive market growth is forecast to be 1% in the final quarter, civil aero programmes continue to ramp-up, but at a slower rate than previously expected.

Military aerospace and agricultural end markets look set to continue their decline. CY17 P/E of 9.2x, an EV/EBIT of 8.7x and DPS yield of 3%.

Apropos of AT&T, of course.

11:51 am
BE

Deal rationale for AT&T
AT&T’s move to acquire TWX would give it the ability to offer differentiated bundles to consumers
through distributing premium content in a seamless way across multiple screens. AT&T has stated the
deal will increase its dividend cover and diversify the business towards less regulated, less capex intensive
revenue streams.
Read across - Europe already advanced in convergence
For the read across to European Telecoms, we see AT&T/TWX as a different flavour of convergence than
is prevalent in Europe. Convergence combines mobile, fixed and pay-TV into a single bundle. This
reduces churn and offers the opportunity to cross sell. We note that AT&T is following in the footsteps of
Comcast that already owns NBCU. For Europe, convergence has focused on the combination of fixed
and mobile assets. Content is important to telecom operators in driving mobile data usage (see our
recent sector note) and offering more services in a bundle, but we think European operators have a
preference for wholesaling content from a neutral third party.

BE

Sky a beneficiary from European convergence
We see Sky as a beneficiary of convergence as it benefits from additional distribution/wholesaling
opportunities with the telecom operators and Sky has a critical mass of premium content in the UK, Italy
and Germany for a relatively lengthy window. While we think VOD remains focused on a broader deal
with LBTY, as we have stated recently (see our recent note), Sky could be a strategic alternative for VOD
should a broader deal with LBTY not go ahead. We note that in New Zealand VOD is merging with Sky
Network TV and a VOD/Sky deal would give VOD scale in UK broadband and offer differentiated content
to bundle with mobile in a similar vein to AT&T/TWX.
Sector M&A back on the agenda
European Telecoms has underperformed YTD on lack of M&A and lacklustre earnings momentum.
However, AT&T/TWX could bring M&A back into focus for Europe, particularly on convergence related
deals. We think investor expectations are low on sector earnings momentum and in-line Q3/Q4 results
could reassure. We see the sector as cheap on 7% EFCF yield and 5% dividend yield for 2017.

BE

PM

“The companies must focus on their market position vis-à-vis competition, and not compare themselves to their own past. The drive must be on leadership rather than to follow,” he said, addressing Managing Directors and senior leaders of Tata companies.

Mr. Tata said, “I look forward to working with you as we have worked together in the past. An institution must exceed the people who lead it. I am proud of all of you, and let us continue to build the group together.”

He asked the leadership of the companies to focus on their respective businesses, without being concerned about change in leadership. Referring to ongoing initiatives in the companies, he said, “We will evaluate and continue to undertake those that are required to. If there is any change, they will be discussed with you.”

Mr. Tata reiterated that he had assumed the role of the Interim Chairman for stability and continuity so that there is no vacuum. “This will be for a short time. A new permanent leadership will be in place,” he emphasised.

Tata Sons has already announced that a Selection Committee has been constituted to choose a new Chairman, and will complete its mandate in four months.

PM

11:57 am
BE

Housing market uncertainty, etc.

Countrywide PLC (CWD:LSE): Last: 193.00, down 9 (-4.46%), High: 197.40, Low: 186.90, Volume: 908.95k
BE

We are reducing our CY2016 EPS estimate by 24% and our CY2017 EPS estimate
by 31% as a result of weak housing transaction data from the Land Registry,
weak mortgage approval data and our view that Countrywide will scale back
its expansion for as long as stamp duty levels and Brexit uncertainties temper
activity in the UK housing market. We cut our PT to 180p and move our rating
from Buy to Hold.

11:57 am
BE

Weak transaction data. The Land Registry published transaction data for June last week.
Transactions in England were down 32% year on year and down 54% in inner London. In
the year to 30 June, housing transactions are down 5% in England and 16% in inner London.
Stamp duty changes + Brexit uncertainty = trouble. The last two stamp duty
changes have, in our view, disrupted the UK housing market, slowing the upper end of the
market and leading to unusual behaviour in the buy-to-let market. What should have been a
period of short-term pain, while price expectations adjust, is still slowly playing out. We also
believe that the creation of a two-tier stamp duty market acts as a brake on transaction levels.
When we add 'Brexit uncertainty' into the mix, potential homebuyers have more reason to
play a waiting game with respect to house purchases, and falling transaction levels are a key
driver of our estimate cuts today.
Expansion plans on hold... The UK housing market and political landscape have changed
significantly since the 'Building Our Future Strategy' was launched one year ago. In our view,
it is no longer the right time for M&A. We have therefore scaled back our assumptions on
M&A activity, which was a significant part of the expansion strategy. We have also reduced
margins to reflect the fact that when housing transactions slow, operational gearing turns
from friend to foe.
Are left-field events like buses? We did not accurately forecast the result of the EU
referendum; could the Autumn Statement adjust stamp duty, making our PT cut somewhat
premature?

BE

Valuation/Risks
Valuation: At 205p, Countrywide trades on a CY2016E PER of 9.9x and offers a yield of
5.4%. Our 180p PT is based on long-run PER and EV/EBITDA multiples weighted 1/3 to our
Neutral Scenario 1/3 to our Upside Scenario and 1/3 to our Downside Scenario.
Risks: While the group has a deliberate and broad diversification of business units, it is
exposed in many forms to the underlying UK housing market; weakness/strength in house
prices, transactions or the private rented sector may lead to changes in our estimates.

Here's Shore.

BE

Sirius is developing the paradigm-shifting North Yorkshire polyhalite project (henceforth, ‘the project’) in England. The company has devised a two-stage construction financing plan, and the first pieces of Stage 1 have fallen into place today. Australian billionaire Gina Rinehart’s Hancock Prospecting has agreed to provide US$300m of the US$1.09bn Stage 1 requirement, comprising US$250m in royalty financing and US$50m in equity funding. We see this as a resounding endorsement of the project, given that Hancock (as Sirius puts it) is “such an experienced party in the mining industry and also one with a strong agricultural interest”.

· Equity investment would be concurrent with royalty drawdown: Hancock’s US$50m equity investment would occur concurrently with drawdown by Sirius of funds from the royalty financing. We understand from Sirius that the issue price will be determined following further progress with remainder of the Stage 1 financing package.

· Royalty equivalent to 3.6% on 20Mtpa: In return for providing US$250m, Hancock is to receive 5% of the gross revenue on the first 13Mtpa of sales for each calendar year, and 1% for any volumes above 13Mtpa (effectively, 3.6% on 20Mtpa at steady-state production). This will continue for the longer of the life of the project or 70 years. The royalty financing agreement is conditional upon completion of Stage 1 financing, and two confirmatory due diligence items that will be satisfied prior to the ‘remainder’ of the Stage 1 equity and structured capital raises being finalised.

· Confidence in production profile implied: The Hancock funds will become available once Sirius has expended US$630m of the total amount of the Stage 1 financing (the total includes the Hancock funds). The royalty returns an IRR (yield) of c.19-21% (depending on exact timing of drawdown) on our 20Mtpa 50-year ‘base case’. With 20% typically targeted by mining investors, this implies confidence in the production profile’s achievability, we believe.

· Good progress on two-stage financing plan: According to Sirius, “good progress” continues to be made on its two-stage financing plan. Details of (the remainder of) the Stage 1 capital structure and timing will be subject to further announcement “at an appropriate time.

We continue to anticipate the conclusion of Stage 1 financing during the autumn of 2016. If all goes to plan, there would be no further need to raise equity thereafter, dilution would cease to be a concern, and we believe the resulting improved clarity on potential equity returns could trigger a significant re-rating. While Sirius is currently at development stage and still some years from becoming a cash flow-generating company, an investment in Sirius will become progressively de-risked and should enjoy significant value uplift as it advances towards production, we believe. Our latest Risked NPV estimate is 70p/share post-Stage 1 financing (previously: 75p/share); we reiterate our BUY recommendation.

12:07 pm
BE

MP Evans has reported interim results for the period ending June 2016. This was always going to be a tough period
financially: the CPO price has been fairly subdued, especially given this is likely to be the period of output most affected by
last year’s El Nino. Given these factors, it is not surprising that the H1 crop was down 9% YoY. However, extremely good
extraction rates lead to CPO production that was actually up 1.5% YoY; in our view, an extremely good result in the
circumstances. Further, the new mill at Banka is now operational which should lead to a significant amount of additional
crop being processed into CPO in H2. Revenue was US$30.4m, down 20% YoY, reflecting the weak CPO price but EBIT
was US$5m, 10% up YoY reflecting more favourable exchange rates. Net profit was at a similar level to the prior year once
gains on the cattle disposals have been stripped out. Overall, we feel this is a good performance in the market
environment that existed in H1 and it is pleasing to see that the CPO price has strengthened substantially so far in H2 and
currently sits at US$755/tonne, its highest level since mid-2014. Our forecasts are already take into account the tough El
Nino-induced operating factors and, given that these should ease in H2, while production should rise as crop yields start to
revert to the norm and the new mill adds to production, we are not changing our forecasts at this stage. We continue to
believe that MPE is a growth value play, with substantial output growth to come to the end of the decade (given a
maturing estate), a very strong balance sheet (thereby minimising operational risk) and a valuation that leaves
considerable upside (sum-of-the-parts local comparables). We retain our Buy rating and 565p price target.
